title: 105_hr1632
content: EMPLOYER-PROVIDED EDUCATIONAL ASSISTANCE. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to extend the exclusion for educational assistance programs and restore the exclusion for graduate education expenses. The amendments apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1996. The exclusion for educational assistance programs and graduate education expenses applies to expenses for courses starting after December 31, 1996. SEC. 2. DEDUCTION FOR INTEREST ON EDUCATION LOANS. an amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to include a new section for deducting interest on education loans. The deduction for interest on education loans allows individuals to deduct the interest paid on qualified education loans during the taxable year. The deduction is subject to limitations based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. The deduction for interest on education loans is subject to limitations based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income, which is determined without regard to certain sections and after the application of specific adjustments. The $50,000 and $80,000 amounts are subject to inflation adjustments for taxable years beginning after 1997. The $50,000 and $80,000 amounts for the deduction of interest on education loans will be increased annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment. If the adjusted amount is not a multiple of $5,000, it will be rounded down. No deduction is allowed for dependents. For the taxable year, an individual can claim a deduction for qualified education loan interest if another taxpayer claims a deduction for the same individual under section 151. The term 'qualified education loan' refers to debt incurred for qualified higher education expenses, paid within a reasonable period, and attributable to education received while the recipient was at least a half-time student. The term 'qualified education loan' includes debt used to refinance qualified education loans, excluding debt owed to a related person. 'Qualified higher education expenses' refer to tuition and fees for the taxpayer, spouse, or dependents eligible for a deduction. The taxpayer can deduct expenses for an eligible student at a higher education institution, excluding certain sports, games, or hobbies unless they are part of the degree program. The eligible student must meet specific requirements and carry at least half of the full-time workload for their course of study. The term 'institution of higher education' refers to an institution eligible for programs under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965, including those offering internship or residency programs. The terms 'full-time student', 'half-time student', and 'dependent' are defined in relation to the course load and tax implications. Special rules include denial of double benefits and the requirement for married couples to file joint returns. Married couples must file joint returns to claim deductions, as per marital status determined by section 7703. The deduction for interest on education loans is allowed regardless of itemizing other deductions. Reporting requirements are amended to include information on transactions with other persons. SEC. 6050S requires reporting of education loan interest received in trade or business from individuals. SEC. 6050S mandates reporting of education loan interest received in trade or business from individuals if it totals $600 or more in a calendar year. The return must include the individual's name, address, TIN, and the amount of interest received. SEC. 6050S requires reporting of education loan interest received from individuals totaling $600 or more in a calendar year. The return must include the individual's name, address, TIN, and the amount of interest received. Governmental units are treated as persons for this purpose, with special rules applying to them. Statements must be furnished to individuals for whom information is required. Every person required to make a return under SEC. 6050S must provide a written statement to individuals showing the name, address, and aggregate amount of interest received. The statement must be furnished by January 31 of the following year. The term 'qualified education loan' is defined as per section 221(d)(1). The term 'qualified education loan' is defined as per section 221(d)(1). In the case of interest received on behalf of another person, only the person first receiving the interest is required to make the return under subsection (a). Section 6724(d) of the Code is amended to include returns relating to education loan interest received. The Code is amended to include returns relating to education loan interest received in trade or business from individuals. Additionally, clerical amendments are made to the table of sections for part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Code. The Code is amended to include returns relating to education loan interest received in trade or business from individuals. The amendments apply to qualified education loans incurred before or after the enactment date, specifically for loan interest payments due after December 31, 1996.
